#########################################################################################################
## Key information for projecting species distributions under climate change 
#########################################################################################################


Aim: Quantify which species - from a list - will can survive and thrive in Australian urban environments
under climate change predicions (2050, 2070, 2100, etc.). Although the analyses specifications will evolve
over time, there are some key bits of information that we need, regardless of the particular datasets or 
settings used (e.g. which rasters, algorithm settingsm etc.).

First, we need an ecological framework for the environmental conditions affecting plant growth, reprodcution 
and distribution. Guisan and Zimmermans (2000) framework has achieved wide currency, and applies regardles 
of the landscape.

#########################################################################################################
## 1).Read in species data
#########################################################################################################


The whole analysis runs off one table which contains data for 510 ecological plot sites in the Wet Tropics. 
This table contains the coordinates for all sites, the response variable (primary productivity), environmental 
conditions (rainfall and temperature), and the explanatory variables (rainfall and temperature niche width): 


